awd_titl_txt: Student Travel Grant for 2021 Formal Methods in Computer-Aided Design (FMCAD)
awd_abstract_narration:
Formal Methods in Computer Aided Design (FMCAD) 2021 is the 21st in a series of conferences on the theory and applications of formal methods in hardware and system verification. It provides a leading forum to researchers in academia and industry for presenting and discussing ground-breaking methods, technologies, theoretical results, and tools for reasoning formally about computing systems. This grant will help support conference travel for up to 10 students enrolled in US institutions to attend FMCAD in San Jose, California October 23-25th 2019. The students will get the opportunity to present at the Student Forum, which is a platform for graduate students at any career stage to introduce their research to the wider Formal Methods community, and solicit feedback.

Formal methods is being rapidly deployed in a variety of areas both in academic research as well as in industrial systems. Thus the broader significance and importance includes fostering the next generation of researchers in this research area, as well as providing international experiences to build a globally-aware workforce. In particular, students will have the opportunity to present at the Student Forum, learn state-of-the-art methodologies, be exposed to novel techniques, and interact with senior researchers in their areas of expertise. The organizers will give priority to students from under-represented groups and from small universities without a formal methods program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since its inception in 2013, the FMCAD Student Forum has been a catalyst for innovation and collaboration in the field of Formal Methods, giving students the opprtunity to present their research to experts in the field. The intellectual merit of this initiative is evidenced by the student work, which features cutting-edge research findings and techniques developed by undergraduate and graduate students.

This project was originally intended to support selected US-based student travel to the FMCAD Student Forum in 2021, but due to COVID, FMCAD 2021 was hosted remotely and so the student forum did not require funding support for travel. This project was extended in its scope to support selected US-based students for the FMCAD Student Forum 2022 and present their work.

This tenth edition of the FMCAD Student Forum in 2022 marked a significant milestone, featuring 20 exceptional accepted submissions covering diverse topics like automated reasoning, software and hardware verification, and applications to security and biology. An independent program committee ensured a rigorous review process, emphasizing novelty, impact, and positive effects on both the Formal Methods community and participating students.

Beyond the immediate disciplinary boundaries of Formal Methods, the outcomes of the project have made a broader impact on various academic and industrial domains. The findings presented at the forum contribute to the knowledge base in artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, bioinformatics, and concurrent programming. A key achievement is the mentorship and collaborative learning opportunites created for these US-based students at the forum.

We extend our gratitude to the National Science Foundation for supporting this project and recognizing the importance of fostering collaborative learning, innovation, and skill development among the next generation of researchers in Formal Methods.
